chunks.content: Hesburgh is also credited with transforming the face of Notre Dame by making it a coeducational institution.

metadata.relevance_reason: This statement directly addresses the type of educational institute Hesburgh is credited with creating at Notre Dame.
metadata.answer_contribution: This indicates that Hesburgh is credited with making Notre Dame a coeducational institution.

chunks.content: In the mid-1960s Notre Dame and Saint Mary's College developed a co-exchange program whereby several hundred students took classes not offered at their home institution, an arrangement that added undergraduate women to a campus that already had a few women in the graduate schools. In 1971 Mary Ann Proctor became the first female undergraduate; she transferred from St. Mary's College. In 1972 the first woman to graduate was Angela Sienko, who earned a bachelor's degree in marketing.
